reviewText: I have been searching for this movie for years!! When I was a child, our family use to 'camp out' on the living room floor and watch "Chiller Theater" in Columbus, Ohio. This movie was so scary for me as a child, and I loved it, but could never find it. I came across it looking for old 'campy' Halloween movies and couldn't believe that I finally found it! Of course by today's standards it's old and corny, but I still loved it-If I could find a better quality DVD I would buy it. This particular movie was grainy due to age, and very 'low tech' but for me I watched every minute of it
I generally like 50s era "B" movies, but this one is terrible. Stiff acting, combined with elementary school special effects result in an awful film. I feel cheated even though it was free.
Cheesy 50's (1959 Ford was the only clue I had) movie, Beast/spider a joke. Ending dumb.  Even Plan 9 from Outer Space was better.
This movie was not filmed in 3-D. This release is computer generated and manipulated. They are placing two slightly offset images in a stereo window and it does not have true depth.

A drive-in classic b-movie, presented here for the first time in 3D. This disc doesn't include any pair of 3D glasses and it can be viewed on any DVD or Blu-ray player (it doesn't have to be a 3D Blu-ray deck). It can work only on 3D monitors and television screens with both passive or active glasses. You just need to adjust your 3d Television to side-by-side view. As far as movie-making goes, there are some serious issues here. As far as campy fun for those of us from South Dakota, there are some serious nostalgia factors in play.
Without giving all the locations away, let's just say if you are familiar with the northern Black Hills you will recognize several spots. It's fun to see the Deadwood area way before legalized gambling took over.
The story needs a lot of help and the not-so-special effects are horrible, but it had me thinking about what a modern remake would be like.
Don't waste time
Classic cult movie

I love black and white movies. this movie is about thugs who find a way to rob a mining company of a few bricks of gold. their alibi is taking a ski trip to a remote cabin  somehow they wake up a creature that has been sleeping for a long time.  Then things start getting interested. And in the end its the bad guys who save the day (unwillingly) while at the same time getting their just dessert.
Old black and white. Can't beat it
this movie is soooooo cheesy, the cotton candy monster is so funny, still, this movie is way better than what they make now.
Awful.lol
I only watched this because I remembered seeing it when I was little girl.  Its not a great picture - just "campy fun."  This would have been great for Mystery Science Theater.
old cheesy 50's scifi.  Love it.

I'm a fan of old horror, even the old "B-movies".  "Beast from the Haunted Cave", however, has few redeeming qualities.  Honestly, I'm a bit surprised by the positive reviews.  The acting is wooden.  Production quality is poor.  And the story... What story?

Ostensibly the "Beast" has two plots:  a crime drama and a monster.  Of the two, the crime aspect is the better.  It lacks any real drama, but I at least cared some about the two protagonists.  The monster movie seemed almost an afterthought.  I can almost hear the producers saying, "gee, maybe if we throw in the popular horror angle, we can get this sticker to make money."  The "Beast" was in the backdrop through most of the movie, but it added little value to the plot.  MINOR SPOILER  Skip to the next paragraph if you don't want some hint at the ending.  In fact, the movie just "ended".  I don't want to give any details.  Suffice it to say that I wasn't satisfied in the role the Beast played in the outcome or in the resolution of the crime-drama aspect of the movie.

One of the few ways I enjoyed the "Beast" was related to the quality of this reproduction.  It was so common to have visual or audio issues related to the original filming or loss in storage that it became a bit of a game.  "What's that on the screen?"  "What's the noise?"  There were so many places that the noise overcame the spoken track that I eventually turned on CC to be able to follow the dialog.

A group of thieves pull off a big gold heist, then head out for a remote, mountain cabin to hide out. Little do they know, that a terrifying creature has been tracking them, after they inadvertently destroyed its mine-shaft nest. BEAST FROM HAUNTED CAVE is another low-budget horror / monster film from 1959 (Yes, Roger Corman was involved). The characters are interesting, w/ actual individual personalities. The mixed genre plot works well, adding a certain realism to the proceedings. The BEAST itself is a wondrous creation of fuzzy, tentacle-waving cheeeze. Yet, it is quite effective! It comes across as quite a macabre abomination w/ a memorable screech. The scene showing its first victim, webbed to a tree, scared me to death as a kid! The cave-lair finale was fuel for many a nightmare! BFHC is proof that lack of funds needn't be an obstacle in movie-making...

This movie was so scary for me as a child, and I loved it, but could never find it. I came across it looking for old 'campy' Halloween movies and couldn't believe that I finally found it! Of course by today's standards it's old and corny, but I still loved it-If I could find a better quality DVD I would buy it. This particular movie was grainy due to age, and very 'low tech' but for me I watched every minute of it

Without giving all the locations away, let's just say if you are familiar with the northern Black Hills you will recognize several spots. It's fun to see the Deadwood area way before legalized gambling took over.
The story needs a lot of help and the not-so-special effects are horrible, but it had me thinking about what a modern remake would be like.
Don't waste time

All the interest of boiling oatmeal interrupted here and there with a slap-and-tickle. Gray, mumble-y scenes and weather reports. Beast? What beast? You mean the cigarello-smoking jerk? Or the comic relief who failed to relieve?
South Dakota. Really.
Creature costume budget was less than $20.
It was awesome cheesy fun. The monster is great!

Basically, "Beast From Haunted Cave" is a weak, unoriginal heist story with a cheesy monster thrown in to make in marketable, if just to kids and teens in the late 50's. Yet, there's something about it I've always liked. Although I don't remember seeing it when it came out, or on TV in the 60's, it's just the kind of movie my friends and I loved...monster movies...any and all monster movies. I found it about 10 years ago in a multi pack of public domain sci-fi and horror movies. I've watched it many times since for it's nostalgic charm.

It works as well as it does because the characters and the dialogue are fairly interesting, and the monster adds a special ingredient...cheeze. The horror is not well integrated into the crime story, but for those who enjoy 50's and 60's cheeze, that's not a deal breaker.

Produced by Roger Corman's little brother Gene, I prefer this film to most of Rogers movies from this era.

Not recommended to anyone who isn't already a fan of this stuff, but who else would even bother reading these reviews?
None
Needs to be remastered for picture and sound though that won't help the poor plot, writing and acting.
